Award.AwardTitle: High School Teacher Training in Bioinformatics - Boston, MA, July, 2014

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Since 2012, high school Advanced Placement Biology exam includes molecular evolution and suggests using open-access NCBI BLAST engine for sequence database search to illustrate principles of gene evolution and its applications in biotechnology. BLAST has many other uses in school curriculum. The goal of the proposed workshop is to give teachers, including those working at schools serving high numbers of students from categories underrepresented in STEM, an understanding of the functionality of the sequence databases and methods of their search.

Pairing the proposed workshop with ISMB 2014 will provide teachers with an opportunity to interact with researchers to discuss the science, techniques, and posters from the Bioinformatics Education Special Interest Group, which will be displayed at the conference on the day of the workshop.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The International Society for Computational Biology (ISCB) conducted a high school teacher training at the 2014 Intelligent Systems for Molecular Biology (ISMB) conference in Boston, Massachusetts, July 11, 2014. This applied one-day training opportunity provided 20 high school teachers a hands-on tutorial using bioinformatics tools. The hands-on workshop was taught by Dr. Fran Lewitter, Dr. David From (biology teacher at Nashoba Regional High School) and Dr. Patricia Palagi, (Head, Training and Outreach, Swiss Institute of Bioinformatics). The workshop included bioinformatics activities that can be used in a high school classroom to help students learn biological principles. This applied tutorial provided teachers with a strong platform on how to use the tools and in turn use the techniques in the classroom, allowing the opportunity to spike curiosity in computational science and encouraging students to pursue the study in the future.  The awarded NSF grant No. MCB-1443425 was used to support this workshop. 

As of 2012, the Advanced Placement (AP) Biology exam includes Evolution as an area of study and introduced BLAST as methods for teachers to use with students to teach evolutionary principles. Although the labs provided to teachers by the College Board are useful, this workshop provided more background to teachers so that they have a better understanding of BLAST and other tools that can be used in AP Biology classes as well as other Biology classes.

The design of the workshop gave teachers with the information necessary to easily add or duplicate the hands-on activities as a computational lesson to their course curriculum and all of the resource materials are fully available for use on the ISCB website.  Furthermore, teachers also had the opportunity to interact with seasoned computational researchers to discuss the science, techniques, and posters from the Special Interest Group, which were displayed at the ISMB conference on the day of the workshop.

ISCB fully promotes STEM and recognizes the importance of impacting future scientists at a young age. We also acknowledge the increased competition and standards that universities and advanced academic institutions are requiring.  Providing this workshop strengthen the understanding of the BLAST tool incorporated into the Advanced Placement Biology exam.  STEM promotion goes beyond just science, educating teachers and encouraging the inclusion of a computation lesson in their curriculum advances the awareness of the computational biology scientific discipline.  A rare mix of mathematics, computer programming, and science, computational biology is a discipline that will continue to gain popularity within scientific research.  It is important to introduce this science at the high school level and we believe our hands-on tutorial allowed this introduction to take place and resonate with students encouraging them to explore the discipline in their future studies.  ISCB believes that mathematical and computational components applied to biological problems will lead to scientific discovery related to health and disease. Introducing computational biology at the high school level is important to generate an interest in this field at a formative stage in the educational process.
